Russian President Dmitry Medvedev has delivered his annual Address to the Federal Assembly. See the highlights @KremlinRussia_E.
We need to modernise our economy and create growth incentives in all spheres, taking democratic values as our base.
We need to raise generations of free, educated, creative Russians and qualitatively improve people's standard of living.
Our main objective for the economy is to bring down the inflation rate to between 4% and 5% within the next three years.
Obligatory social insurance payments for small businesses in production and in the social services will remain at 26% in the next two years.
Russian-made pharmaceuticals should account for 50% of the market in a few years, up from the current 20%.
In Skolkovo, tax benefits and government funding for research will be available to anyone who has ideas and meets the qualifications.
Modernisation is above all for the younger generations. We should not be ashamed of the country we leave to our children and grandchildren
We must improve the quality and accessibility of medical care and social services for mothers and children.
We will discuss allotting land free to families at the birth of their third and every child beyond that, to build a house or summer cottage
There should be no unwanted children in Russia. Child protection agencies must focus on promoting adoption and supporting adoptive families
We must foster dialogue with those who care about the environment before launching construction of production and infrastructure facilities
Modernisation gives rise to a smart economy, but also requires smart policies and new standards for government agencies.
The understanding that an official serves the nation rather than decides its fate is the basis of a democratic system
The state acquisitions law remains purely aspirational. A massive amount of public money is wasted. It needs to be reviewed and modernised.
European missile defense plan leaves two options: mutual understanding with NATO or a possible arms race, which is not desirable.
Everything we do is for our children, so they can live better and be better than us. So their success shapes Russia's future. Let it be so.

The President spoke of his priorities, such as promoting civil and economic freedoms
Any juxtaposition of freedom and order, freedom and prosperity or freedom and justice is absolutely wrong
The President spoke on Russia's economic performance in the past few years
This year has seen the lowest inflation in recent years: 4% in the past 12 months
Average economic growth has stabilised at about 4%
In the past two years, Russia has seen the lowest level of poverty in its modern history
Over 400 Russian companies are Skolkovo residents. Even if only 10% of them succeed, we will rejoin the group of global technology leaders
On the business climate in Russia: A talent for business should be considered a vital social value
The biggest problem for businesses and investors is the unpredictable interference of officials in economic activity
The list of state-controlled companies will be posted in 2 months, to be followed by debate on whether they should keep this status
The resources that regions and municipalities manage and use independently must be expanded by 1 trillion roubles over the next few years
To implement all our programmes, we do not need to increase taxes but above all enhance the efficiency of budget expenditure
I support the idea of introducing the institute of a special prosecutor or an ombudsman to protect the rights of businessmen
The President commented on political reforms
People’s direct involvement in political processes at this stage will not prod us back to chaos, but make the state more efficient
The demographic policy: The Russian population did not decrease last year, for the first time in many years
Dmitry Medvedev spoke of the key indicators for assessing the efficiency of government bodies
First and foremost, in six years life expectancy in Russia should increase by at least four years
Second, the share of families with incomes below the subsistence level must be cut to less than 10% in five years
Third, in five years Russia must climb to number 40 in international rankings on the ease of doing business, and rank with top 20 by 2020
Fourth, Russia needs to create at least 25 million new, highly productive jobs, mainly in non-commodity sectors
In several years from now, the unemployment rate must be under 5% and labour productivity must grow by 50% to 100%
Fifth, at least five Russian universities must be in the top 100 in the leading international ratings
Sixth, most Russian families should have the opportunity to upgrade their housing no less than once every 15 years
Seventh, Russia must be among the top ten countries with high presence of electronic technology in all areas of society's life
